## How does the portal bridge this gap? 

::: {.incremental}

* Provides a **<span style="color:#1696d2;">one-stop-shop</span>** for 100+ datasets released by government agencies and other institutions on schools, school districts, and colleges in the U.S. 
* Includes harmonized **<span style="color:#1696d2;">data</span>** and **<span style="color:#1696d2;">metadata</span>** for each dataset
* Makes it easier for users to look at **<span style="color:#1696d2;">trends over time</span>** and **<span style="color:#1696d2;">combine data</span>** from different sources 

:::

## Using the portal **<span style="color:#1696d2;">R package</span>**...

**Example**: How has tuition at my alma mater changed?

. . . 

::: columns
::: {.column width="55%"}

```{.r code-line-numbers="4"}
library(educationdata)

# Get data 
data <- get_education_data(
  level = "college-university",
  source = "ipeds",
  topic = "academic-year-tuition",
  filters = list(
    year = c(1990:2020), 
    unitid = "173258", 
    tuition_type = "4"
  )
)

# Plot data 
data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = tuition_fees_ft)) +
  geom_line()
```

:::
::: {.column width="45%"}

![](images/carleton-tuition-plot-r.png){.absolute top=200 left=580 width="500"}

:::
:::

## Using the portal **<span style="color:#1696d2;">Python package</span>**...

**Example**: How has tuition at my alma mater changed?

::: columns
::: {.column width="55%"}

```{.python code-line-numbers="4"}
import educationdata 

# Get data 
data = get_education_data(
  level = "college-university",
  source = "ipeds",
  topic = "academic-year-tuition",
  filters = {
    "year": range(1990, 2020), 
    "unitid": "173258", 
    "tuition_type": "4" 
  }
)

# Plot data 
data.plot.line(
  x = "year", y = "tuition_fees_ft"
)
```

:::
::: {.column width="45%"}

![](images/carleton-tuition-plot-python.png){.absolute top=200 left=580 width="500"}
